title: First Message Nerves
situation: You matched with someone you really like. You’ve been staring at the chat box for 10 minutes, afraid of saying the wrong thing.
question: What do you send as your opening message?

choices.label: “Hey.”
choices.outcome: They might reply, but it doesn’t give them much to work with. The conversation starts flat.
choices.insight: Low-effort openers lead to low-energy conversations. You don’t need to be clever, just specific.

choices.label: “Hey, I saw you love hiking. What’s your favorite trail you’ve ever done?”
choices.outcome: You show you actually read their profile and give them a fun, easy question to answer. The chat feels more alive from the start.
choices.insight: Pointing at something specific in their profile makes you stand out from generic messages.

choices.label: A long paragraph telling your entire life story and what you want in a partner.
choices.outcome: It can feel intense for a first message. They may feel pressure to respond perfectly or not at all.
choices.insight: You can be sincere without oversharing. First messages work best when they’re light and open-ended.

title: Late Reply Anxiety
situation: You had a great back-and-forth with someone yesterday. Today, they haven’t replied to your last message for 9 hours.
question: What do you do?

choices.label: Send three follow-up messages asking if everything is okay.
choices.outcome: You come across as anxious and they may feel pressured or overwhelmed.
choices.insight: Stacked messages can turn natural delays into uncomfortable pressure.

choices.label: Do nothing for now and focus on your own day.
choices.outcome: You give them space to reply in their own time. When they do, the conversation feels more relaxed.
choices.insight: Not everyone lives in their messages. Allowing space respects both of your lives outside the chat.

choices.label: Unmatch them immediately so you don’t have to feel uncertain.
choices.outcome: You protect yourself from uncertainty but also cut off a potentially good connection prematurely.
choices.insight: Ending things quickly to avoid discomfort can keep you safe, but it can also limit opportunities.

title: Choosing a First-Date Plan
situation: You’re about to suggest a first date. You want it to feel low-pressure but not boring.
question: What do you suggest?

choices.label: A long fancy dinner at an expensive restaurant.
choices.outcome: It can feel high-pressure and hard to leave if there’s no chemistry.
choices.insight: First dates usually work better when there’s an easy ‘exit’ and the option to extend if it’s going well.

choices.label: “Want to grab a coffee and walk around the park near [place] this weekend?”
choices.outcome: It’s casual, public, and gives you both something to look at besides each other.
choices.insight: Simple, time-limited plans reduce pressure and make it easier to relax into conversation.

choices.label: “Come over to my place and we’ll see what happens.”
choices.outcome: For many people, this feels unsafe or overly sexual for a first meeting.
choices.insight: Inviting someone to your home too early can send signals you may not intend and reduce their sense of safety.
